rounds.observation:
[GAME] You are Player 0 in a 2-player Texas Hold'em Poker game.
Your goal is to win chips and outlast opponents through strategic play.
Game Information:
- 10 hands total
- Starting stack: 1000 chips
- Blinds: 10/20

Here are examples of good poker decision-making:

Example 1: Pre-flop with pocket aces (A♠ A♥), facing a small bet. Action: '[Raise 50]' because pocket aces are the strongest starting hand and should be played aggressively to build the pot.

Example 2: You have 7♣ 2♦ (worst starting hand) and opponent bets big. Action: '[Fold]' because this hand has almost no chance of winning and continuing would waste chips.

Example 3: You have a strong flush draw on the flop, opponent checks, pot is 100 chips. Action: '[Bet 40]' to take control and potentially win immediately, or build pot for when you complete your draw.

Example 4: You're short on chips (only 200 left) and have A♠ K♦ facing a big raise. Action: '[Call]' or '[Raise 200]' all-in because AK is strong enough to risk your tournament life with a short stack.

Available actions (exact tokens):
  '[Check]'  - when no bet is live
  '[Call]'   - match the current bet
  '[Fold]'   - discard your hand
  '[Bet N]'  - open for N chips
  '[Raise N]'- raise by N chips

Invalid actions will result in retries. Use exact bracket format and ensure you have sufficient chips for bets/raises. Check when facing a bet is invalid.

With pot = 40 and no bet in front of me, checking keeps the initiative with Player 0 while giving me one more free card.  
[Check]

Visible board: [5♦, 7♣, 4♦]  
P0 (Dealer/BB): 980.00 chips | bet 0.00 | active

Your hole: J♦, 9♠  
My action: With J♦ and 9♠ on a board of 5♦, 7♣, 4♦, I have Jack high with a gutshot straight draw (needing an 8) and a backdoor flush draw. This is a weak hand, so I'll check to see the turn without committing more chips.  
[Check]

rounds.response:
I hold A♦ 10♠ with the board showing 5♦ 7♣ 4♦ 6♥. Although I have just ace-high, I picked up an open-ended straight draw: any 3 or 8 now gives me the nut straight.

My opponent has checked both the flop and the turn, suggesting either (1) they have a weak holding or a marginal made hand that fears bigger board runouts, or (2) they are planning to showdown cheaply with something like a small pair or busted draw. With both of us deep, betting here charges drawing hands and builds a pot for when I hit my straight or another scare card rolls off.

Sizing: a turn bet of roughly 60-70 % of the pot is standard—enough to squeeze value out of worse holdings that will still call, but also to set up potential river pressure if I brick. I’ll use 65 % of the 40-chip pot:

[Bet 26]
